abstract.p: National Institute of Ethics survey finds that number of complaints filed against municipal police in New Jersey rose from 6,208 in 1995 to 9,025 in 1997 and dropped to 8,688 in 1998 (S)

block.p: The number of complaints filed against municipal police in New Jersey increased dramatically between 1995 and 1997, according to a survey of the years 1995 through 1998 done by the National Institute of Ethics, a leading provider of police ethics training based in Winter Park, Fla. The complaints reached a high of 9,025 in 1997 compared with 6,208 in 1995. In 1998, the number dropped to 8,688. Essex and Hudson Counties topped the list with the most complaints. The complaints ranged from excessive use of force to police corruption.

The number of complaints filed against municipal police in New Jersey increased dramatically between 1995 and 1997, according to a survey of the years 1995 through 1998 done by the National Institute of Ethics, a leading provider of police ethics training based in Winter Park, Fla. The complaints reached a high of 9,025 in 1997 compared with 6,208 in 1995. In 1998, the number dropped to 8,688. Essex and Hudson Counties topped the list with the most complaints. The complaints ranged from excessive use of force to police corruption.
